thread.title: Year of the Rooster celebrations unite Asian communities across North Texas
thread.title_full: Year of the Rooster celebrations unite Asian communities across North Texas

author: Deborah Fleck
title: Year of the Rooster celebrations unite Asian communities across North Texas

organizations.name: u.s. pan asian american chamber southwest
greater dallas taiwanese chamber of commerce
north texas collin county taiwanese chamber of commerce
greater dallas asian american chamber of commerce

text:
Get Unlimited Digital Access Your first month is less than a dollar. $0.99 for first 4 weeks Subscribe Now 
North Texas is embracing the Lunar New Year. Celebrations of the Year of the Rooster have taken place in libraries, shopping centers such as Cali Saigon in Garland and Asia Times Square in Grand Prairie, hotel ballrooms, restaurants and at the Crow Collection of Asian Art in downtown Dallas, which hosts one of the holiday's largest festivals. 
A banquet and celebration hosted by the Greater Dallas Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce drew more than 1,000 guests Friday at the Intercontinental Hotel in Addison. Emceed by Ramey Ko and Kelley Liu, the event included keynote remarks by Don Casey of American Airlines, greetings from several elected officials and entertainment. The chamber also presented Global Vision Awards to Amy Lewis Hofland, executive director of the Crow Collection; Gary Cook, chancellor of Dallas Baptist University; and Sam Coats, DFW Airport board member. Funds raised will benefit the chamber's International Sister City program and the Student Ambassadors Exchange Program. Amy Hofland (center), executive director of the Crow Collection, is presented the Global Vision Award during the Greater Dallas Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce's annual Lunar New Year Gala. (Deborah Fleck) 
On Saturday, the North Texas Collin County Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce hosted its Lunar New Year festivities at Renaissance Hotel in Richardson and the Organization of Chinese Americans-DFW held its 31st annual banquet at Kirin Court in Richardson. 
One more celebration is planned this Saturday. The U.S. Pan Asian American Chamber Southwest have its celebration at the Asian Banquet Center in Arlington. For tickets, call 682-323-5869 or email justin@uspaacc-sw.org. 
New officers Rosa Oh, immediate past chair of the Greater Dallas Asian American Chamber of Commerce, receives a gift from new chairman Kamal Kaushal. (Deborah Fleck) 
The Greater Dallas Asian American Chamber of Commerce keeps growing. At its annual membership meeting Thursday hosted by Homa Bash of KXAS-TV (NBC5), the chamber inducted its new officers. They are chair Kamal Kaushal, chair-elect Christel Roco, secretary Daisy Chen, treasurer Thomas Kim and immediate past chair Rosa Oh, who will continue to serve on the chamber board of directors. 
Seven vice-chairs and 27 directors also were elected. Dallas County Judge Clay Jenkins conducted the installation ceremony before everyone squeezed together for a group photo. 
Learn more at gdaacc.com . Jamie Ford (Laurence Kim) 
The 21st annual Highland Park Literary Festival announces Jamie Ford will be its keynote speaker. The author of Hotel on the Corner of Bitter and Sweet and Songs of Willow Frost , Ford will talk about his writings at 7 p.m. Feb. 23 at Highland Park High School, 4220 Emerson Ave. 
His works of historical fiction explore the lives of Asian-Americans in the Seattle area. Ford, who is of half-Chinese descent, is now working on a young adult series. 
For more about the festival, visit hplitfest.com . 
Upcoming events 
Tuesday 
Eboo Patel will speak at 7 p.m. in Nicholas Martin Hall at Texas Wesleyan University, 1201 Wesleyan St. in Fort Worth. Free. Learn more at ifyc.org . 
Friday 
The Artists Showplace Gallery, 15615 Coit Road, presents "Flow," an exhibit featuring water color artist Stephen Zhang, through March 4. A reception will be from 5:30 to 9 p.m. Friday with music by jazz saxophonist Ray Baker. Free. Find more at theartistsshowplace.com . 
Ongoing 
The Jaycee Park Center for the Arts, 1925 Puritan Drive in Irving, presents "Indian Folk Art" through Feb. 24. Free. Call 972-721-2488. 
Feb. 17 
The Japan-America Society of DFW presents a program on U.S.-Japanese relations under the Trump administration from noon to 3:30 p.m. at the InterContinental Hotel, 15201 Dallas Pkwy. in Addison. Luncheon speakers will be Joseph Young and Dr. Haruo Iguchi. Panelists will be Junji Kurokawa, Tim Keith and Howard Kass. $45-$55. Registration required by Monday. Go to jasdfw.org.
